properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A disturbance tracking across the central Kivalliq is bringing snow and blowing snow to most of the region today and persisting into tonight. Snow has begun along the southern coastal areas of the Kivalliq and will persist into the evening hours before tapering off overnight. Total snowfall accumulations of 5 to 10 cm are expected by Monday morning with lesser amounts of 2 to 4 cm likely in the Arviat area. Along with the snow, strong southerly winds are expected to develop later this afternoon gusting at times to 70 or 80 km/h. These winds combined with the falling snow will produce near blizzard conditions at times especially during the late afternoon and early evening hours. Winds are expected to diminish later this evening into the overnight hours. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-07T07:59:17-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-06T20:15:17-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3970858951.2020
Area: Arviat, Rankin Region including Whale Cove
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A series of weather systems will impact the North Coast Inland region (including Kitimat) with heavy rain beginning this afternoon and persisting into Monday morning. During this period, rainfall amounts of 50 to 80 mm are forecast. The heavy rainfall will ease in intensity Monday morning. Due to recent significant rainfall, the ground is already near saturation and has less ability to absorb further rainfall. The upcoming period of heavy rain may bring higher than normal impacts to the region. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-07T11:01:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-06T19:02:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2249992223.2020
Area: North Coast - inland including Kitimat
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An intense low pressure system is affecting the Eastern Quebec today. For areas of the North Shore, snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 centimetres are expected over Sept-Îles and Havre-Saint-Pierre, and over the western part of Anticosti Island today. In addition, strong winds gusting to 60 or 70 km/h accompanying this system will greatly reduce visibilities in blowing snow. Motorists should be prepared to deal with changing road conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-07T07:35:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-06T15:36:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3572292545.2020
Area: Baie-Trinité area, Sept-Îles - Port-Cartier area, Minganie, Anticosti
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An additional 5 to 10 centimetres of snow is expected tonight. In addition, the combination of snow and strong winds will cause local blowing snow. Weather conditions will improve Monday morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-07T12:35:14-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-06T20:36:14-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2492309181.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A disturbance tracking across the central Kivalliq will bring snow and blowing snow to most of the region later today and tonight. Snow is expected to begin along the southern coastal areas of Kivalliq this afternoon and persist into the evening hours before tapering off overnight. Total snowfall accumulations of 5 to 10 cm are expected by Monday morning with lesser amounts of 2 to 4 cm likely in the Arviat area. Along with the snow, strong southerly winds are expected to develop this afternoon gusting at times to 70 or 80 km/h. These winds combined with the falling snow will produce near blizzard conditions at times especially during the late afternoon and early evening hours. Winds are expected to diminish later this evening into the overnight hours. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-07T05:59:53-00:00

Area: Arviat, Rankin Region including Whale Cove
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: 10 to 20 centimetres of additional snow, strong winds and blowing snow. An intense low pressure system over the Gulf of St Lawrence this evening will affect Eastern Quebec through Monday morning. This system will bring snow at times heavy overnight over several areas of the Gaspé Peninsula especially those near the river. This storm will also be accompanied by strong winds gusting up to 80 kilometres per hour. These winds combined with snow will reduce visibilities to near zero locally over these areas. Meanwhile, the strong winds combined with high tide could produce breaking sea conditions over the Northeastern Gaspé Peninsula area early this evening. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-07T12:36:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-06T20:37:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1452116916.2020

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected to continue today and tonight. Additional snowfall: 5 to 15 cm. Locations: central and western New Brunswick Time span: today until early Monday. Remarks: For the Fredericton, Stanley, Doaktown and Blackville regions, rain is expected to change over to snow this afternoon. Elsewhere, snow is expected to continue today and ease overnight tonight. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall is expected over some areas. Total snowfall: 5 to 10 cm, except near 15 cm inland and over higher terrain. Locations: Labrador Straits. Time span: tonight. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, will develop this evening. The snow will become mixed with rain and ice pellets near the coast before easing to showers or flurries near midnight. Snow will remain dominant inland and over higher terrain, with significant accumulations expected. Conditions are forecast to improve over most areas by early Monday morning. For anyone considering travel beyond Red Bay: road closures are possible. Very heavy snowfall is expected along portions of the Trans-Labrador Highway. Please refer to warnings for adjacent areas for further details. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Summary:
Description: 10 to 15 centimetres of additional snow, strong winds and blowing snow. An intense low pressure system is affecting Eastern Quebec and will spread snow at times heavy today over the Lower St. Lawrence and the Gaspé Peninsula areas. This storm will also be accompanied by strong winds gusting up to 80 kilometres per hour. These winds combined with snow will reduce visibilities to near zero locally over these areas. Otherwise, strong winds combined with the high tide could produce breaking sea conditions over the northeastern coast of the Gaspé Peninsula late in the day Sunday. There is also a risk of freezing rain over the Eastern Gaspé Peninsula this morning. Poor weather will persist through Monday over the northern section of the Gaspé Peninsula. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Dense fog continues to persist in the Interlake and regions east of Lake Winnipeg. In the Interlake, fog is mostly confined to the west shores of Lake Winnipeg but is slowly expanding southwards. Dense fog is expected to persist or redevelop tonight as a ridge of high pressure remains in the region. This fog advisory may be expanded as the evening progresses and conditions are monitored. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Fog advisories are issued when near zero visibilities in fog are expected or occurring. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. An approaching low pressure system tracking across the Kivalliq is bringing snow, strong winds and blizzard conditions to Chesterfield Inlet this afternoon. Falling snow combined with wind gusts up to 80 km/h is leading to significantly reduced visibilities. Blizzard conditions are expected to persist until late this evening when winds will diminish. Total snowfall amounts will be in the 5 to 10 cm range before tapering off on Monday morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-07T08:00:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-06T20:15:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2647186489.2020

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard conditions have developed near the Richardson Mountains today as a trough of low pressure has deepened over the Yukon. Easterly winds of 80 gusting to 100 km/h near Rock River have generated near zero visibility in snow and blowing snow. The trough will weaken on Monday morning and then deepen again late Monday afternoon.. Blizzard conditions are expected to end early on Monday morning and then redevelop on Monday night. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snowfall amounts are expected. Total snowfall: 25 to 35 cm, except 45 cm inland and over higher terrain. Time span: tonight through Monday night. Locations: Cartwright to Lodge Bay. Remarks: The heaviest snow will occur tonight and Monday morning, with snowfall rates gradually easing later Monday into Monday night. The snow may mix with rain along parts of the coast between Norman Bay and Lodge Bay Monday afternoon and night. Strong northeasterly winds gusting to 60 km/h accompanying the snow will cause reduced visibility in blowing snow over some areas, mainly inland and over higher terrain where temperatures will be colder. For anyone considering travel: road closures are possible. Very heavy snowfall is expected along portions of the Trans-Labrador Highway. Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Dense fog continues to persist in regions east of Lake Winnipeg early this afternoon. Some improvement is expected through the afternoon hours but dense fog is expected to redevelop tonight as a ridge of high pressure remains in the region. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Fog advisories are issued when near zero visibilities in fog are expected or occurring. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-07T09:26:21-00:00

Area: Poplar River, Berens River, Little Grand Rapids and Atikaki Prov. Park, Bloodvein
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An additional 5 to 10 centimetres of snow is expected today. In addition, the combination of snow and strong winds will cause local blowing snow. Weather conditions will improve overnight Sunday. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-07T08:36:20-00:00
